org.orgName: United States District Court Western District of Washington Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, SOUTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of YO YOU JAM, for Writ of Habeas Corpus.} No. 3395 POINTS AND AUTHORITIES.

It is contended comended that the judgement of the Immigration authorities upon the question of citizenship is final, but this judgement must be sound and not capricious, and founded upon substantial evidence. A citizen of the United States, or a son of a citizen of the UNited States cannot be banished from his home upon insufficient suspicion conjecture and distrust. That the Immigration Department did not fully have the case in mind, and did not give the subject the full and careful hearing which the law requires is demonstrated by the ruling of the Hon. Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, which ruling in set forth in the transcript, and in as follows:

"After carefully considering the evidence presented in the above entitled matter I find that YO YOU JAM is not the minor son of a domiciled exempt, as claimed, but in more than twenty- one years of age, a married man, the father of one child and therefore the head of a household of his own.

It is order that he be and he is hereby rejected, and denied admission to the United States and that he be returned to the country whence he came to wit, China, by and at the expense of the steamship company bringing him to this country. Henry M. White, Commissioner."

It will be noticed that the petitioner is excluded from the United States on the ground that he is not the minor son of a domiciled exempt, as claimed. The petitioner in this notion did not seek admission as the minor as the minor son of a domiciled exempt, but did, and is seeking admission into the United States as the son of his father, who is a native born citizen of the United States.

The Commissioner did not make any finding upon the relationship of father and son. Subsequently thereto, however, on June 20, 1916, John H. Sargent, a deputy Commissioner, made a further finding and Order, as follows:

"After carefully considering the evidence presented in the completed record in the above entitled matter, I find that YO YOU JAM is not the son of Yo Bing Goe, as claimed, but is an alien Chinese, not a member of any of the exempt classes, and not entitled to admission to the United States.

It is ordered that he be and he is hereby rejected and denied admission to the United States, and that he be returned to the country whence he came, to-wit: China, by and at the expense of the steamship company bringing him to this country. John H. Sargent, Commissioner."

This matter involves a serious question; the status of the father as an American citizen is not in question; that Yo Bing Goe is a native born citizen of the United States is admitted. Therefore, if the petitioner of this country cannot be denied If he, your petitioner, was seeking admission as a citizen of the United States, the finding on that question, if based upon sound judgement and without abuse to the substantial rights of the applicant, would be final. But the question herein involved presents an entirely different proposition. The question presented, is Yo You Jam, the son of Yo Bing Goe, and we do most earnestly contend that upon that important question, a decision by a political officer is not final, but is subject to review by this Honorable Court; that the status of the offspring of a citizen of the United States can not be fully and finally determined by a political officer.

"The law recognizes nop distinction of color or race in the parental relation, but all parents, whatsoever may be their standing in society, have precisely the same authority and control over their children." People vs. People, S Howard Practise, N.Y.

"Parents have the natural right to the custody and control of their children; the paretns' rights to the custody of the child is, however, not absolute, but subject to the judicial control when the safety or the interests of the child demand it, and must yield whenever the real or permanent interest demand it." Cyc. SO Practice, Vol. 29, p.15.
"The rights of parents are, however, entitled to great consideration, and courts should not deprive the parent of the custody of his child without good cause." Cyc. Vol. 29, p 1588.

"The law watched with jealous care, and courts will assumed jurisdiction over children whenever the safety or welfare of the child demands it. So, in this case, the Petitioner sets forth the fact that he is a native born citizen of the United States, and that his safety demands of this court the protection that a child of a native born citizen is entitled to. The rights and obligations of parents and child does not necessarily continue or terminate upon the child's attaining majority, but may, by consent, continue in full force after such time." Cyc. Vol. 29, p. 1583

The petitioner contends that he is being subjected to the deprivation of rights, privileges and immunities secured to him by each of the following provisions of the Constitution of the United States, to- wit: First- "Nor shall any state deprive any person of life or liberty, without due process of law." Second- "Nor deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the law."
The petitioner in this case is being deprived of there rights, privileges and immunities under color of that section ofthatcertain of Revised Statutes of the United States. November 3rd 1890

The acts set forth in petitioner's petition for a writ of Habeas Corpus were done under color of any statute, ordinance, regulation, custom or usage of any state or territory, subjects, or causes to be subjected any citizen of the United States, or other person within the jurisdiction thereof, to the deprivation of any rights, privileges or imunities secured by the Constitution and laws, shall be liable to the party injured in an action at law, suit in equity or other proper proceedings for redress."

Lord Eldon in DeManneville vs. Demannevile, 10 Ves. 52, said that he, as Judge, exercising the authority of the king, as parens patriae, removed children from the custody of the father, when he thought such custody unsuitable.

In Storey's Equity Jurisprudence, p. 1341, the author says: "The jurisdiction of the court of chancery extends to the care of the person or infant for its due management and satisfaction and proper application for its maintenance; it is upon the former principal, that is to say, for the due protection and education of the infant that the court interferes with the ordinary rights of parents, as guardians by nature or by nurture. Wherever the parents are in constant habits of drunkeness or blasphemy or low and gross debauchery, or that the domestic associations are such as to tend to corrupt and contaminate the children, in every such case, the court of chancery will interfere and deprive the parents of the custody of the children, and appoint a suitable person to act as guardian and to take care of them and superintend their education."

If, under the common law, the King stood as paren patriae and removed children from the custody of their parents when he thought such custody unsuitable, and if a state has jurisdiction to remove children from the custody for their protection and education, the Government, acting through the court, certainly has the power to take the child of an native born citizen from a political officer who has unjustly deprived him of a substantial right, and particularly so, where that political officer threatend to legally banish the child from the country of his father's nativity. We admit that the mere quetion of citizenship is determined by the Immigration Department, but we most earnestly contend that the relationship existing between a native born citizen of the United States and his son is not finally determined by a political officer; but that a child seeking to establish his statue as the offspring of a citizen is entitled to have a judicial determination upon that question.

We further contend that there is no evidence to sustain the findings of the Commissioner, but on the other hand, there is substantial evidence to establish the fact that the petitioner is the son of Yo Bing Goe. Whether or not this petitioner shall be bastardized and banished from the land of his father's nativity, and whether or not a citizen of this country shall be deprived of the society, service, aid and comfort of his son is the issue herein involved. The sacred rights of parent and child cannot, we believe, be finally determined by a political officer. If so, then no citizen is safe in permitting a son or daughter to leave the United States.
Respectfully submitted, John J. Sullivan Attorneys for Petitioner.
